item.title: Join coala chat and set up your accounts
item.description:
During Google Code-in, the mentors and other participants will be chatting to you in our chat forums like Zulip and Gitter (and we also use Telegram and IRC!), reviewing Pull Requests on GitHub, Merge Requests on GitLab, and other collaborative services too!

To make it easier, it's essential for you to have a globally available username.

Steps

Join Zulip

First join our Zulip chat server at https://coala.zulipchat.com/ , using the same email address that you used when registering for Google Code-in.

Choosing your global username

Think of a username that you would like to use, and check if it is available globally. e.g. if you want to use username foo

Some basic checks can be at https://username-check.herokuapp.com/, and more checks can be done at https://knowem.com/checkusernames.php?u=<username>.

Keep trying different usernames until you have found a username that is not used by anyone else!

If you want to keep your existing username, contact any of the mentors.

Create your accounts with your globally available username

  1. GitHub.com
  2. GitLab.com
  3. OpenHub.net
  4. openSUSE (https://connect.opensuse.org/)
  5. Behance (see help ) or Deviantart (https://www.deviantart.com/)

Note

Select your email as "Public email" at https://github.com/settings/profile. Go to https://github.com/settings/emails & uncheck "Keep my email address private".

Submit your user profiles

In your Google Code-in task instance, add links to your profiles on those services.

For more information, see the zulip stream

External URL: https://coala.io/#/getinvolved

item.title: tldr-pages: page request: dep
item.description:
Create a new tldr page on the command dep. Helpful links to the documentation for dep are available in the description of the issue on GitHub associated with this task.

If you decide to create this page, comment on the issue to let others know that you're creating it.

Once you've created it, send a Pull Request to the main tldr-pages repository.

General guidelines on what the page could look like can be found in the contributing guidelines in the main tldr-pages repository. Great example pages include <code>7z</code>, <code>tar</code>, and <code>cd</code>.

If you need additional assistance, you can comment on the issue associated task. You can also send an instant message in the main tldr-pages gitter channel. If you've opened a pull request, then you can also comment on there too.

tldr-pages is a collection of simplified and community-driven man pages. More information about tldr-pages can be found in the readme in the main tldr-pages repository.

To complete this task, it may be helpful to first have investigated and used tldr-pages. A web client is available here - other command-line clients are listed in the readme of the main tldr-pages repository.

External URL: https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/issues/1659

item.title: Add a fact about coala to Wikidata
item.description:
coala is software. coala is an organisation.

This task is to add one fact to Wikidata about either the software or the organisation.

Wikidata facts are being used to automatically create Wikipedia articles, and there are lots of interesting tools and viewers like Reasonator that consume and re-use Wikidata content.

Before claiming this task, please complete one 'medium' difficulty task in the coala organisation.

If you have not edited Wikidata before, read the Introduction and do the Tutorials before attempting this task.

This task involves editing a live database, and any mistakes may immediately impact thousands of other users around the globe. Care and caution are required. Communicate with your mentors.

Not surprisingly, MediaWiki and Wikimedia Foundation are a good example to follow for the way to describe software components in the Wikidata ontology.

If you do not have a Wikimedia account, please ensure your new Wikimedia username is identical to your GitHub username. As a mentor for help if you can not register the same username.

After creating the fact, submit your task with a comment including your contributions URL, such as https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Special:Contributions/Blazeu

External URL: https://github.com/coala/meta/issues/106
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: Add a translation about coala to Wikidata
item.description:
coala is software. coala is an organisation.

This task is to translate an item label on Wikidata, for any item related to either the coala software or the coala organisation.

Wikidata facts are being used to automatically create Wikipedia articles, and there are lots of interesting tools and viewers like Reasonator that consume and re-use Wikidata content.

Wikidata facts can be represented in any language by translating the labels of items. (A property is special type an item.)

Before claiming this task, please complete one 'medium' difficulty task in the coala organisation.

If you have not edited Wikidata before, read the Introduction and do the Tutorials before attempting this task.

This task involves editing a live database, and any mistakes may immediately impact thousands of other users around the globe. Care and caution are required. Communicate with your mentors.

Not surprisingly, MediaWiki and Wikimedia Foundation are a good example to follow for the way to describe software components in the Wikidata ontology.

If you do not have a Wikimedia account, please ensure your new Wikimedia username is identical to your GitHub username. As a mentor for help if you can not register the same username.

After translating an item label, submit your task with a comment including your contributions URL, such as https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Special:Contributions/Blazeu

item.title: Add Codecov to an open source project hosted on GitHub
item.description:
If you are not already familiar with continuous integration and unit testing, please following the steps of our beginner "CI1" task before attempting this codecov task. CI1 will help you do the first three steps of this codecov task.

Find an open source project on GitHub.com in any language and add Codecov through a pull request.

  1. Find an open source project in GitHub.
  2. Fork the project so that you may make edits to the source code.
  3. Connect the CI tool (typically Travis CI, Circle CI and AppVeyor) to run your project changes.
  4. Based on the software programming language(s) used proceed to add the necessary coverage collection tool(s) in order to collect coverage.
  5. Add Codecov uploader to collect and upload coverage reports.
  6. Commit changes in GitHub.
  7. Monitor the CI build to ensure coverage was collected and properly uploaded to Codecov.
  8. If properly uploaded: create a pull request to the source repository.
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: Create funny "loading" sentences to amuse users while they wait
item.description:
Introduction

Wanna test your level of humour? How witty are you against the competition?

Everyone loves funny loading screens, right? GitMate team has been busy concocting some of them. Check out the repositories tab on https://gitmate.io to watch them in action.

Here are some examples..

  • Opening pod bay doors...
  • Waiting for the right moment...
  • Downloading the internet...
  • Testing your patience...
  • Buying some server space...
  • Hang on a second, I know your data is somewhere here...
  • Sending sheep to Mars...
  • Stealing your passwords...
  • Gathering your credit card info...
  • Shovelling coal into our servers...

Objective

Your task is to add more such sentences. Check our the list in issues here. Make sure you don't repeat them.

Once you've got ideas, road test your sentences on your friends to see which of them are more delightful than others and come up with more ideas together with them.

When you've gotten a short list of sentences, create issues on GitLab here following the template for each sentence. Ask your friends to vote the issue and comment on what they like.

Assessment

Your task is considered complete when the following conditions apply:

  • You have opened between 5 and 10 issues with ideas.
  • One of your ideas has at least 5 votes.
  • You have voted for at least as many issues as you created. (don't vote for your own)

EDIT:

The requirement of one of your ideas has at least 5 votes has been put down to at least 3 votes.

External URL: https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/gitmate-spinner-ideas

item.title: Lint translations in weblate projects
item.description:
Locate and fix technical bugs contained in translated messages contained in a weblate project.

Aim

This task aims to help participants gain advanced understanding of text markup and translation file formats, as well as the open source quality check tools available for these file formats.

DO NOT translate messages. That is not the objective of this task.

DO NOT send pull requests.

Your weblate username MUST be the same as your GitHub username, and your email address in GitHub and weblate MUST be identical.

Find 10 bugs in a translation project

Bugs in translated messages include:

  • semantic problems, such as missing grammatical structure, like a missing period at the end of a sentence.

  • syntax errors, such as invariant parts of the source message that have been translated when they should not be translated.

There are existing open source tools that find and even fix these problems automatically. A linter supported by coala DennisBear is <code>dennis</code>. Another open source tool is <code>translate-toolkit</code>, which is included in most Linux distributions.

Choose translations projects in either:

  • https://hosted.weblate.org/ projects
  • https://l10n.opensuse.org/ projects

Register your project

To avoid conflicts, only one participant may work on a project at a time.

Once you have found a project with technical bugs, register it as your project on Zulip in the #gci stream under topic weblate.

Fix 10 bugs

  1. Fix the translation bugs in weblate
  2. Give star to the repo

External URL: https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/admin/continuous.html
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: Your first coala issue - describe a feature for the community repository
item.description:
We have launched http://community.coala.io/ for our GCI website , and it needs features.

This task is to privately discuss a missing feature with a mentor, and then after review by a mentor create a public issue with your description.

Do not create an issue before a mentor has approved your text.

Other GCI organisations also have GCI websites, so you may find inspiration by looking at them. e.g. http://gci17.fossasia.org/ .

However, this website must be re-usable, which means no coala data in the repository, and no mention of coala. All data must be loaded dynamically from webservices, IGitt, or some other 'open data'.

Mentors will help you ensure your idea is feasible.

The process for your first issue is very important.

  1. Write a comment privately in your task instance describing the feature. Your description must be a minimum of 500 characters. Include as much information as you can, including suggestions on how to implement the feature.
  2. Submit your task instance for review.
  3. A mentor will review your description, and they will reply with a private comment, either telling you to improve your description, or their comment will say "PUBLISH!".
  4. If you have been told to PUBLISH, do a quick check of existing issues to prevent duplicates, and then create a new issue in the repository if nobody has beaten you to it .
  5. Submit your GCI task for review.

After you have completed this task, you will be allowed to claim other GCI tasks to create an issue without mentor pre-approval.

External URL: https://github.com/coala/community/issues

item.title: CI1: Use coala
item.description:
Objective

Use coala CI on a popular GitHub project, of your choice, using a Docker image on Travis CI, and create a wiki page recording the coala output.

See our coala GCI task wiki page for step by step instructions using only a web browser.

Background

coala unifies code analysis. It provides a single simple user and a developer interface, wrapping many popular code analysis tools, and provides a native code analysis framework for new tools. Demo

More documentation on coala can be found at http://docs.coala.io .

Requirements

A GitHub account. This activity is done entirely using a web browser in your own repositories on GitHub, and does not involve interacting with other repositories, or installing or using any software on your own computer. Join us on our gitter channel where we are very active and happy to help you!

Expected Outcome

* You are NOT expected to submit any changes to another OSS project in this beginner task. * Accepted work by mentor following steps here

Note: There is a separate GCI task for submitting your changes to other OSS projects, which you can commence after a coala developer has reviewed and accepted your work for this task.

https://github.com/coala/coala/wiki/Google-Code-In-Task-Use-coala
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: coala-html: Setup CI for building Github Pages
item.description:
Make gh-pages branch in coala/coala-html repo be rebuilt automatically from master on each push to master using Travis CI.

On a fork, the build should not push to upstream gh-pages, instead it should do a push to gh-pages branch on the fork.

A push to a branch other than master on a fork can overwrite the gh-pages, but that would still be a bit messy. Instead write it into gh-pages/<branch_name>. Then, the fork owner can set which branch is published in the repo settings on GitHub. See this documentation.

Additionally, on each pull request, Travis should build the commit on that pull request without overwriting the gh-pages.

External URL: https://github.com/coala/coala-html/issues/133
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: linterhub: Create a Docker image for golint
item.description:
Task

Create a Docker image with Alpine Linux for the golint linter.

Register an issue

  • Register an issue about missing linter golint: https://github.com/repometric/linterhub-docker/issues/new

Fork repository

Fork the linterhub-docker repository.

Build

Find an Alpine-base image on Dockerhub with a go preinstalled (golint requires Go 1.6 or later).

Create a new Dockerfile based on the previous one and install the linter golint (and dependencies if needed). e.g. https://github.com/repometric/linterhub-docker/blob/master/engines/jshint/Dockerfile

Please do not install unnecessary dependencies!

Build container, make sure there are no errors during build.

Manual tests

  1. Run the golint linter on a sample go project using golint installed on your computer

  2. Perform the same analysis using your container bash docker run -v /local_folder:/container_folder -it linterhub/your_favorite_engine engine_command Make sure that outputs are equal.

Automated tests

Introduce a simple test as described above using Automated Test: https://docs.docker.com/docker-cloud/builds/automated-testing/#set-up-automated-test-files (ensure that expected analysis results are equal to the actual results).

Submit a PR

Once you've finished, please submit a PR to linterhub-docker.

External URL: https://github.com/repometric/linterhub-docker

item.title: linterhub: Create a Docker image for csvlint
item.description:
Task

Create a Docker image with Alpine Linux for the csvlint linter.

Register an issue

  • Register an issue about missing linter csvlint: https://github.com/repometric/linterhub-docker/issues/new

Fork repository

Fork the linterhub-docker repository.

Build

Find an Alpine-base image on Dockerhub with a ruby package manager that can install csvlint.

Create a new Dockerfile based on the previous one and install the linter csvlint (and dependencies if needed). e.g. https://github.com/repometric/linterhub-docker/blob/master/engines/jshint/Dockerfile

Please do not install unnecessary dependencies!

Build container, make sure there are no errors during build.

Manual tests

  1. Run the csvlint linter on a sample CSV file using csvlint installed on your computer

  2. Perform the same analysis using your container bash docker run -v /local_folder:/container_folder -it linterhub/your_favorite_engine engine_command Make sure that outputs are equal.

Automated tests

Introduce a simple test as described above using Automated Test: https://docs.docker.com/docker-cloud/builds/automated-testing/#set-up-automated-test-files (ensure that expected analysis results are equal to the actual results).

Submit a PR

Once you've finished, please submit a PR to linterhub-docker .

External URL: https://github.com/repometric/linterhub-docker

item.title: Use GitMate CI
item.description:
Objective

Use GitMate CI on a GitLab project and report the results to #gitmate channel on coala.zulipchat.com.

Background

GitMate is a tool to automate maintenance tasks on GitHub and GitLab projects. It provides automated code review using a static code analysis tool, called coala. More documentation can be found at https://docs.gitmate.io.

Requirements

A GitLab account. This task is done entirely using a web browser on your forked repository of example-setup on GitLab, and does not involve interacting with other OSS projects, or installing any software on your computer.

Join us on our Zulip channel at https://coala.zulipchat.com where we are active and ready to help!

Visit the link below for more details.

External URL: https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/GCI/wikis/Tasks/Use-GitMate-CI
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: Design a new logo for corobo
item.description:
This task involves designing a new logo for the coala bot, corobo.

Be creative and make it aesthetically associated with corobo! You must be able to explain how your design relates to corobo. Before doing this task, you should have completed at least one 'newcomer' level task for corobo, and have interacted with corobo on gitter.im and Zulip. Let the bot inspire you!

You must submit a completely original design of your own creation that does not use 3rd party images from the web, unless they are licensed under Creative Commons licenses. If you create a design similar to something you found on the web, it is considered a derivative work and you should give proper attribution (i.e., credit) to that author by name with a link to their work. Failure to give credit is plagiarism and can be grounds for dismissal from GCI. When in doubt, design something unique. ;)

Logo design tips are in abundance around the web such as these 65 tips and these 7 tips.

Familiarity with a graphics design package like Gimp & Inkscape (open source & free), or Photoshop & Illustrator (not free) are useful for completing this task.

Upload your original artwork files in a vector format (e.g., PSD, XCF, SVG, AI, etc) to either https://www.behance.net/ or https://www.deviantart.com/ , with the same username as you have used for GitHub. Your uploaded files must be licensed under Creative Commons Sharealike. The winning design will be announced after all design entries have been assessed.

External URL: https://github.com/coala/corobo/
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: Add CONTRIBUTING.md on vulture
item.description:
Add a CONTRIBUTING file to vulture. It should include the following information: * How to setup a virtual environment? * How to install the development version of vulture? * Coding standards - Ensure that people send a PR from a branch other than the master branch. - How to name the branches? * How to send a Pull Request? * Be polite and wait for reviews * Take feedback positively!

Some examples may be found here: https://coala.io/newcomer

External URL: https://github.com/jendrikseipp/vulture/issues/101
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: autocomplete-python: Improve test coverage
item.description:
The goal is to add as much tests as possible, since right now the test coverage of autocomplete-python is close to zero.

To start, you must have Atom installed. Clone the repository using git clone git@github.com:autocomplete-python/autocomplete-python.git and use apm link autocomplete-python to link the git repository as installed package in Atom. Use apm test to run the actual tests (they will fail by default, since the APIs been changed and nobody has fixed them).

Tests are located in spec directory with one example, which tests the actual completions.

Things to test, each as a separated task instance: * Fix existing test to pass * Go to definition command * Complete argument command * Override method command * Show usages command * Rename command (possibly with separated files as well) * Extra paths for packages config create a dummy package and make sure that that dummy library is included in completions when setting is set * Autocomplete function parameters config (none, all, required) test each of them and make sure the output is correct * Regex to trigger autocompletions config make sure that completions are NOT triggered if it does not match this config (e.g. in your test set this config to ([a-zA-Z0-9]*) and make sure that completions are not triggered by . (dots)) * Use fuzzy matcher for completions make sure that turning this off works as intended

External URL: https://github.com/autocomplete-python/autocomplete-python/tree/master/spec
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: autocomplete-python: Investigate process spawning issues on windows
item.description:
A lot of users has reported that python process which is being spawned to access completions isn't closed properly the goal is to track down the issue and try to find a solution.

To start, you must use windows and have Atom installed. Clone the repository using git clone git@github.com:autocomplete-python/autocomplete-python.git and use apm link autocomplete-python to link the git repository as installed package in Atom, so you can preview how your changes affect it. Note that every time you change the code you need to reload your atom window from command palette (Window: Reload).

External process spawning is done via BufferedProcess (which could be a source of problem) which is called from provider.coffee:34:84. Note that process is being killed after 10 minutes, you may need to adjust this value to see how it will behave.

Please submit a pull request with your solution or comment your findings in an issue.

External URL: https://github.com/autocomplete-python/autocomplete-python/issues/310
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: Enhance coala Newcomers guide to state a single PR per issue
item.description:
The Newcomer guide doesnt specify that the contributor should try to submit only a single PR for each issue. The Newcomers guide should convey that otherwise, it makes it tough for reviewers to see if previous changes have been accommodated in current commit or not.

External URL: https://github.com/coala/coala/issues/4770

item.title: Stylelint: Support regex literals in all options that accept regexes
item.description:
Some stylelint rules accept regex literals (e.g. selector-class-pattern) but others do not (e.g. declaration-property-value-blacklist). We need somebody to update the rules that do not to use regex literals.

External URL: https://github.com/stylelint/stylelint/issues/3008
item.dc:creator: coala

item.title: JSHintBear: Upgrade JSHint
item.description:
Update the version of JSHint used by JSHintBear to the latest version.

JSHintBear currently uses JSHint version 2. The latest version is 2.9.5.

In order to upgrade the version used, one needs to have a knowledge of coala's dependency_management. What needs to be changed is the NpmRequirement. Some things may need to be redesigned to accomodate.
item.dc:creator: coala
